did.abstract: Records of the Michigan Land Use Institute, a northern-Michigan based environmental and regional planning organization. The Institute uses local programming and local and statewide political lobbying to establish an approach to economic and physical development that strengthens communities, limits suburban sprawl, and protects Michiganâ€™s natural resources. This record group contains correspondence, reports, conference papers, and publications related to the organization and its goals.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Materials were donated to the library in July of 2007 by the Michigan Land Use Institute (donor no. 9102).

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Michigan Land Use Institute records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Keith Schneider started the Michigan Land Use Institute in 1995 as an outgrowth of the Michigan Communities Land Use Coalition, a small, all-volunteer grassroots organization based out of Manistee County. The organization's founding document indicates that the goal of the Michigan Land Use Institute is to safeguard the land and life of northwest Michigan through managing population growth, natural resource and agricultural policies, and the negative environmental impact of suburban sprawl in northwest Michigan. Mr. Schneider and the founding board of the Institute established an office in Beulah, Michigan and hired a full time staff of experts in areas such as land use planning, sustainable agriculture, waste management, energy efficiency, education, and public policy to design programs and policies to address these issues. The organization's focus has broadened throughout its existence to include addressing these and similar issues on a statewide as well as local level.

In 2000 Keith Schneider stepped down from the role of Executive Director to take on the position of the Director of Program Development, and, in 2003, the additional role of deputy director of the institute. Hans Voss took over the role of Executive Director in 2000 and under his directorship the Institute has expanded considerably, establishing regional offices in Lansing, Grand Rapids, Harbor Springs, and Traverse City and becoming one of the largest state-based environmental and land use policy advocacy organizations in the country.

Since its inception, the Institute has sought to become a resource for other community organizations through conducting research, amassing a library of conservation and land use related material, publishing reports and pamphlets on these issues, and conducting seminars and workshops for community groups. They have also implemented a number of community programs, including the Michigan Land Stewardship Program, the Transportation and Land Use Initiative, New Entrepreneurial Agriculture Program, the Michigan Energy Reform Coalition, the Public Trust Alliance, and the Grassroots Support Center.

scopecontent.p: The Michigan land Use Institute Records contain materials dating from the Institute's inception in 1995 through 2006 and originating from a number of different offices and administrative units. The collection has been divided into five series, Legal, Library, Policy Files, Program Files, and Visual and Electronic Materials.
The Legal series contains legal briefs, case notes, Freedom of Information Act requested documents, and correspondence relating to a number of land use legal cases in northern Michigan.

did.unittitle: Great Lakes Oil and Gas Drilling
Department of Environmental Quality/Department of Natural Resources 2002-2004

scopecontent.p: The Library series includes a number of publications and reports, authored by MLUI as well as other individuals and organizations, that document environmental and land use planning in Michigan. These publications include local zoning codes, materials from conferences organized or attended by MLUI staff members, and reports and publications relating to issues of water quality and use as well as transportation issues and alternatives. The series also includes printed screenshots from the organization's web page as well as a copy of this web page on CD-ROM.

did.unittitle: Agendas and Other Material Relating to Environmental and Land Use Conferences Held in the State of Michigan
Land Use and Regional Planning Materials
Land Use and Smart Growth Materials
Land Use and Environmental Planning Materials
MPSO Trends Futures Reports for Michigan

scopecontent.p: The Policy Files, 1995-2006, include the records of the Statewide Policy Director, Charlene Crowell; the Policy Director, Arlin Wasserman; Policy Specialist, Mac McClelland; and Transportation Policy Coordinator, Kelly Thayer. Charlene Crowell's files are further subdivided into the subseries Administrative, Historic Preservation, Land Use, Smart Growth Detroit, Transportation Policy and Various Policy Files. Of these, the Smart Growth Detroit subseries, which contains correspondence and meeting minutes relating to the Institute's programs and partnerships aiming to limit sprawl and create more livable communities in Detroit and Southwest Michigan, is particularly notable, as is the Transportation Policy subseries, which includes research into Michigan's transportation policy and various public transit options as well as documenting Ms. Crowell's participation in Michigan's 2003 Transportation Summit. Arlin Wasserman's files include the subseries Oil and Gas Rights and focus on MLUI's successful lobbying efforts to prevent oil and gas drilling in the Great Lakes. This action eventually led to a permanent state ban on such drilling. Mac McClelland's files are broken down into the subseries Community Projects, Fundraising, Michigan Land Use Institute Organization Structure, Michigan Land Use Institute Projects, Neighborhood Schools Projects, and Policy. The most significant of these is the subseries on the Neighborhood Schools Project, a collaboration between MLUI and the Michigan Chamber of commerce that examined the effects of constructing new schools in suburban or rural locations. This project resulted in the introduction of legislation, developed by the Institute, to integrate school location and decisions with local land use mater planning. A further subdivision is the South Haven Schools Project- a project undertaken by board member Joyce Petter, but falling within the scope of the Neighborhood Schools Project. Kelly Thayer's files include numerous miscellaneous files relating to transportation planning and policy and a sub-subseries related to the debate surrounding a proposed plan to reroute traffic in Traverse City, the Traverse City Bypass.

scopecontent.p: The Program Files, 1996-2005, contain the records of the Leelanau Smart Growth Program Organizer, Johanna Miller; Entrepreneurial Agriculture Program Director, Patty Cantrell; Program Development Director, Keith Schneider; and Program Director, Jim Lively. The Johanna Miller files focus on growing community support for and implementing Smart Growth principles in Leelanau County. The Patty Cantrell files contain documentation of MLUI's Entrepreneurial Agriculture program, a program designed to promote small-scale, entrepreneurial agricultural practices in Michigan. The Keith Schneider files contain program files focusing on growth management and land use and MLUI's role in the 2004 debate over beach access and the public use of the Lake Michigan lakeshore. Jim Lively's files are subdivided into the sub-subseries Smart Growth, covering the implementation of Smart Growth principles in the United States, Wetlands Protection, and two series documenting the Institute's role in protecting Michigan's natural resources for public use--the South Fox Island and Whitefish Point sub-subseries.

scopecontent.p: The Visual and Electronic Materials, series contains photographs of MLUI staff and events as well as slides and negatives of similar material. It also includes two VHS tapes, original material used in the Institute's magazine The Great Lakes Bulletin, and electronic files.
